analyzeResult.content:
The additional $500,000 appropriation by T.I.R.C. for research funds receivedi wide attention also in various parts of the country. New York coverage only is shown here.
THE NEW YORK HERALD TRIBUNE New York, New York January 26, 1955
01138639
$500,000 Added To Smoking Study
The Tobacco Industry Re- search Committee, which last year allocated $500,000 for inde- pendent: research into tobacco use and health, announced yes- terday another allocation of the same amount.
Timothy V. Hartnett, com- mittee chairman, said that its scientific advisory board already has recommended specific grants of more than $300,000, and that the additional allocation was made so that the board would know the minimum it could count on.
The Tobacco Industry Re- search Committee, formed when smoking and lung cancer were linked in reports, is made up of six manufacturing companies and eight organizations of grow- ers and tobacco warehouse asso- ciations.
WORLD-TELEGRAM & SUN New York, New York January 26, 1955:
Tobacco-Health Kitty Doubled
01138639A
The Tobacco Industry Re search Committee: announced today it has doubled its fund for research and will now spend $1,000,000 to determine the re- lationship between use of to- bacco and health, if any.
Timothy V. Hartnett, commit- tee chairman, said $300,000 al- ready has been allocated for re- search projects. He indicated more than $1,000,000 will be made available if research dic- tates use of additional funds.
The committee represents six tobacco manufacturing compa- nies, eight tobacco grower organ- izations and several warehouse associations. The research is be- ing centered on the possible connection between smoking and lung cancer.
NEW YORK DAILY MIRROR New York, New York January 26, 1955
01138639B
A $500,000 fund set up last May by the Tobacco Industry Re- search Committee for independ- ent scientific research into tobacco use and health has been increased to $1,000,000.
Timothy V. Hartnett, com- mittee chairman, said yesterday that the $1,000,000 was "not a ceiling but the minimum sup- port that medical and scientific research can expect from the committee."
The group includes represen- tatives of six tobacco manufac- turing companies and eight or- ganizations of tobacco growers and tobacco warehouse associa- tions. It was formed in Janu- ary. The initial allocation for cancer research in universities, hospitals and other medical in- stitutions was announced in May.
Ten days ago the committee announced nine grants totaling $164,295 for study of the effect of smoking on health. Last Nov. 8 it made six grants totaling $82,084. The Scientific Advisory Board, which is responsible for the committee's research policy and programming, has recom- mended specific grants that now exceed $300,000. Dr. Clarence Cook Little, scientific director and chairman of the advisory board, is director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memor- lal Laboratory, Bar Harbor, Me. He said the board had other ap- plications under consideration.
Mr. Hartnett declared that the committee's earlier pledge of continuing support as needed still stood.
01138639 E
board had recommended grants totaling more than $300,000 from the fund.
Formed last year, the com- mittee sponsors research into
Tobacco Unit Has $1,000,000 Fund
01138639C
The tobacco industry Research. Committee announced Tuesday it had doubled to $1.000.000: its fund for independent research into the use of tobacco and health .. Timothy V. Hartnett, chairman of the committee. said. the new $1,000,000 figure "is not a ceiling. but the minimum support: that medical and scientific research can expect" from the committee. The committee was set up last year following reports that smok- ing might be a cause of lung cancer and heart disease.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL New York, New York January 26, 1955
NEW YORK JOURNAL-AMERICAN New York, New York January 26, 1955
NEW YORK TIMES New York, New York January 26, 1955
STUDY OF SMOKING TO GET MILLION AID
Tobacco Industry Doubles Fund for Research Into Use of Product and Health
01138639 D
Tobacco Research Fund Boosted NEW YORK -The Tobacco Industry Re- search Committee has increased to $1 million its fund for independent scientific research into tobacco use and health, Timothy V. Hart- nett, chairman, announced. An initial'allocation of $500,000 was made last year, and this has now been doubled. Grants of over $300,000 have been recommended by the advisory board.
The committee, formed to sponsor studies of tobacco use and health, consists of repre- sentatives of six tobacco companies and eight organizations of tobacco growers and tobacco warehouse associations.
Lift Tobacco Quiz Fund
The Tobacco Industry Re- tobacco use and health and makes factual information avall- able to the public.
